messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 7/6/2006 8:52:52 P.M. Central Daylight Time,
swords@... writes:



Interesting. If Jim is watching, maybe he could comment on this tsuba.
Again, it seems to have some "age" and the style of decoration (inlay) seems so
unlike Heianjo/Kyoto -- to my eye -- and the lack of kozuka/kogai-Interesting.
If Jim is watching, maybe he could comment on this tsuba. Again, it seems to
have some "age" and the style of de

Ron
STL






ron,
somehow saotome came to my mind....................or may be Onin

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba...kantei?
messages.msgSnippet: Interesting. If Jim is watching, maybe he could comment on this tsuba. Again, it seems to have some age and the style of decoration (inlay) seems so unlike
messages.messageBody:
Interesting. If Jim is watching, maybe he could comment on this tsuba. Again, it seems to have some "age" and the style of decoration (inlay) seems so unlike Heianjo/Kyoto -- to my eye -- and the lack of kozuka/kogai-ana and the kiku shape...while not a super tsuba or anything, I do find it rather interesting to try and understand.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Alan Bale
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, July 06, 2006 5:17 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba...kantei?


Hi Ron Rich,
I don't know why I said Ko-Shoami, it was just a feeling about the decoration. Many years ago I has a Heianjo style brass inlay tsuba signed and dated in the 1560s I think, an unrecorded maker in the provinces, without the signature it would be called Heianjo without a doubt although it had an irregularly punched plate.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, July 05, 2006 11:06 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba...kantei?

Hi Ron, interesting, Alan may be right, but I have a Heianjo guard that
is dated to late Momoyama or early Edo ( guessing Edo ) that has similar
looking iron, the flows are also similar and the scattered leaves are
also Heinajo esk. The scollaped mimi is interesting, I have a couple of
these in my Heianjo book from memory. I will dig it out and have a look.

Rich

I don't know why I said Ko-Shoami, it was just a feeling about the decoration. Many years ago I has a Heianjo style brass inlay tsuba signed and dated in the 1560s I think, an unrecorded maker in the provinces, without the signature it would be called Heianjo without a doubt although it had an irregularly punched plate.
Alan

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tsuba...kantei?
messages.msgSnippet: Unusual motif, most old tsuba with brass inlay are called Heianjo but I wonder if it could be Ko-shoami? Alan ... From: Ron Hartmann To: nihontostudy ;
messages.messageBody:
Unusual motif, most old tsuba with brass inlay are called 'Heianjo' but I wonder if it could be Ko-shoami?
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy ; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 04, 2006 6:47 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Tsuba...kantei?


Happy 4th everyone!

I've just posted a photo in my Yahoo Photos folder (Ron STL) -- Tsuba 147.22 -- which I'd enjoy some opinions on. It is iron with brass inlay, kiku design, measures 86 x 84 x 4 mm in size. Inlay represents mostly leaves with a few flowers. The inlaywork overlaps onto the edge of the tsuba. Inlay is about 90% intact on face, 50% intact on backside. Notice there are no hitsu-ana present.

http://tinyurl.com/mhf6d

This tsuba seems too elaborately inlaid to be called Kyo-zogan and I'm curious if perhaps it might fall more into Yoshiro work. Comments anyone???

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Tsuba...kantei?
messages.msgSnippet: Happy 4th everyone! I ve just posted a photo in my Yahoo Photos folder (Ron STL) -- Tsuba 147.22 -- which I d enjoy some opinions on. It is iron with brass
messages.messageBody:
Happy 4th everyone!

I've just posted a photo in my Yahoo Photos folder (Ron STL) -- Tsuba 147.22 -- which I'd enjoy some opinions on. It is iron with brass inlay, kiku design, measures 86 x 84 x 4 mm in size. Inlay represents mostly leaves with a few flowers. The inlaywork overlaps onto the edge of the tsuba. Inlay is about 90% intact on face, 50% intact on backside. Notice there are no hitsu-ana present.

http://tinyurl.com/mhf6d

This tsuba seems too elaborately inlaid to be called Kyo-zogan and I'm curious if perhaps it might fall more into Yoshiro work. Comments anyone???

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
